explanation:
For checking the MISRA rule forbidding use of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, the analysis must cover all code reachable from the target that could perform such a comparison. Explainations: 
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro): Expands to the object-table lookup used to obtain impl and stream; its expansion may call other helpers or perform name/ID comparisons (possibly using memcmp). The macro definition/source is required to see any string comparisons.
- OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS (macro): Invoked at the end of the function; its expansion may call helper functions that could (incorrectly) use memcmp on C strings. Need the macro body.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (function): Appears in the static call graph and is commonly used by table-lookup macros; it may perform comparisons of identifiers or names. Its implementation must be checked for memcmp misuse.
- OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl (function): Listed as a callee in the static graph (and related to the SET_SOCKET_FLAGS macro); inspect its code for any memcmp calls comparing null-terminated strings.
- OS_stream_internal_record_t (type/struct): Provides context for stream->socket_type and socket_domain; verify whether any field access or derived helpers do string comparisons.
- OS_impl_file_internal_record_t (type/struct): Provides context for impl->fd and any related helper behavior; ensure no hidden string comparisons in its management routines.
- OS_object_token_t (type): Token type passed into macros/functions; its representation may lead to code paths that compare string names (e.g., tokens containing names) — inspect its definition.
- socket (system call): Included to confirm the system/library socket implementation is not performing any memcmp-based null-terminated string comparisons relevant to MISRA rule (generally it won't, but include to be thorough).
- setsockopt (system call): Same rationale as socket — ensure no memcmp-on-strings occurs in the called API paths invoked by this function.

The next analysis should review the source/definitions of these symbols for any use of memcmp comparing null-terminated strings; if none of these contain such uses, the target function and its immediate callees will be safe with respect to the MISRA rule.
